Deep Sea Code Book Robert P. McGuinn 1 Introduction Development note: As of 2019-06-09. this tutorial covers only the basics. New instructions will be added and they will increase in complexity, buiding on what has gone before. This tutorial is designed to help the initail This set of instructions is designed help the R user begin to use the National Database for Deep Sea Corals and Sponges. This is a work in process and we invite collaboration! Please help us evolve this code-base to be easier, faster, and do more things! If you would like to reach out directly please email robert.mcguinn@noaa.gov or call 843-460-9696. 2 Getting data 2.1 Using ERDDAP 2.2 Using a CSV

2 Getting data 2.1 Using ERDDAP Getting data directly from ERDDAP (Environmental Resource Division Data Access Protocol) using ‘rerddap’ package. ##### list all 'table' based datasets on ERDDAP server ##### # x <- head(ed_datasets('table', url = "https://ecowatch.ncddc.noaa.gov/erddap/")) # View(x) # list all 'grid' based datasets on server # x <- head(ed_datasets('grid', url = "https://ecowatch.ncddc.noaa.gov/erddap/")) # View(x) ##### download information about the National Database for Deep Sea Corals and Sponges ##### info <- info(datasetid='deep_sea_corals', fields=c('latitude','longitude','ScientificName', "ImageURL"), url = "https://ecowatch.ncddc.noaa.gov/erddap/") ##### view head of variable names ##### # info$variables ##### ##### # View(out) # d <- tabledap('deep_sea_corals', 'longitude<50', 'latitude>40', 'latitude<60', # fields=c('latitude','longitude','ScientificName', "ImageURL"), # url = "https://ecowatch.ncddc.noaa.gov/erddap/") # # d <- head(d) ##### looking only at the data that has images ##### # d <- d[is.na(d$ImageURL) == F,] # # browse to them # for (i in d$ImageURL){ # browseURL(i) # } # # put them in the RMarkdown document # for (i in d$ImageURL){ # knitr::include_graphics(i) # } # # View(d) # # kable(d) 2.2 Using a CSV Alternatively, if you have the data already you can upload data directly from CSV file into R. # setwd("C:/rworking/digs/indata") # indata <- read.csv("DSCRTP_NatDB_20190418-0.csv", header = T) # filt <- indata %>% # filter(Flag == "0") Take a look at the variable names. head(names(filt)) ## [1] "Flag" "FlagReason" "ShallowFlag" "DatabaseVersion" ## [5] "DatasetID" "CatalogNumber"
3 Filter data 3.1 Filter the data by attributes and geographic extent.

3 Filter data 3.1 Filter the data by attributes and geographic extent. d <- filt %>% arrange(ObservationYear) %>% filter( grepl('Okeanos', Vessel), Latitude > 30, Latitude < 40, Longitude > -130, Longitude < -110 )
4 Mapping 4.1 Creating a Leaflet interactive map 4.2 Importing boundaries 4.3 Creating bounding

4 Mapping 4.1 Creating a Leaflet interactive map Map the selected using a leaflet intereactive map function. library(leaflet) m <- leaflet() m <- addProviderTiles(m, "Esri.OceanBasemap") #Esri.OceanBasemap, "CartoDB.DarkMatter" m <- addCircleMarkers(m, data=d, # lat = x$LatitudeInDD, # lng = x$LongitudeInDD, radius=5, weight=0, fillColor= "green", fillOpacity=1, popup = paste( "CatalogNumber:", d$CatalogNumber, "<br>", "ScientificName:", d$ScientificName, "<br>", "RecordType:", d$RecordType, "<br>", "Vessel:", d$Vessel, "<br>", "DatasetID:", d$DatasetID, "<br>", "SurveyID:", d$SurveyID, "<br>", "SampleID:", d$SampleID, "<br>", "TrackingID:", d$TrackingID, "<br>", "Station:", d$Station, "<br>", "Locality:", d$Locality, "<br>", "ImageURL:", d$ImageURL, "<br>", "Latitude:", d$Latitude, "<br>", "Observation Year:", d$ObservationYear)) m 4.2 Importing boundaries 4.3 Creating bounding

5 Figures and Tables 5.1 Creating figures Using ggplot2 to create a figure describing the depth distribution of a given set of taxa. 5.2 Creating tables
